sections.title: Reinforcement without removing healthy structure
sections.body: Inlays and onlays are custom restorations that sit within or over the biting surface of a tooth. They stabilise weakened areas while preserving more natural enamel than a full crown.

sections.title: What to know before you proceed

faqs.question: How long do inlays and onlays last?
faqs.answer: Longevity depends on bite forces, material, and hygiene. We select materials to match your needs and review the restoration at routine visits.

faqs.question: How do they differ from crowns?
faqs.answer: Crowns cover the whole tooth; inlays and onlays reinforce only the needed areas, preserving more natural tooth when suitable.

faqs.question: Will I need numbing?
faqs.answer: Most preparations are completed with local anaesthetic for comfort. We explain options before starting.

faqs.question: Can they be repaired?
faqs.answer: Minor chips can sometimes be polished or repaired; significant damage may need a replacement. Digital files help us reproduce the fit accurately.

faqs.question: What materials do you use?
faqs.answer: We recommend ceramics or high-strength composites based on bite forces, aesthetics, and the location of the tooth.
